articles.headline: Combating a Flood of Early 401(k) Withdrawals
articles.snippet: Millions of people are clearly not using 401(k) and similar plans as retirement accounts at all, and it’s a threat to their financial health.
articles.abstract: Millions of people are clearly not using 401(k) and similar plans as retirement accounts at all, and it’s a threat to their financial health.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, the Internal Revenue Service announced that people under age 50 in 401(k) and similar workplace retirement plans will be able to deposit up to $18,000 in 2015, an increase of $500 from this year. Those 50 and over can toss in as much as $24,000, a $1,000 increase.

articles.headline: Producer of Highway Guardrails to Halt Sales
articles.snippet: The move comes after regulators ordered more crash testing of the barriers, which have been banned in 13 states because of concerns that they can impale drivers.
articles.abstract: The move comes after regulators ordered more crash testing of the barriers, which have been banned in 13 states because of concerns that they can impale drivers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trinity Industries, facing mounting criticism that its guardrails can impale drivers in crashes, said on Friday that it would stop selling the product, which 13 states have now banned, until further testing could be completed.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Aaron M. Kessler

articles.headline: Abortion Capital of Bible Belt? Tennessee Vote Tests That Idea
articles.snippet: Anti-abortion forces are trying to pass Amendment 1, which states that nothing in the Tennessee Constitution “secures or protects” a right to abortion.
articles.abstract: Anti-abortion forces are trying to pass Amendment 1, which states that nothing in the Tennessee Constitution “secures or protects” a right to abortion.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — The online video features idyllic snatches of Tennessee daily life: guitar players, old barns, church socials — and the official Tennessee welcome sign, glimpsed through the window of a car passing over the state line.

articles.headline: Ottawa Gunman’s Radicalism Deepened as Life Crumbled
articles.snippet: Michael Zehaf-Bibeau was troubled and unstable, and he initially may have sought religion as an attempt to scaffold a disintegrating life.
articles.abstract: Michael Zehaf-Bibeau was troubled and unstable, and he initially may have sought religion as an attempt to scaffold a disintegrating life.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A loner. A drug addict. A criminal. A drifter. And lately, an Islamic radical.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and William Yardley

articles.headline: Administration Will Review Auto Safety Regulator
articles.snippet: The inquiry into the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration comes during a record year for recalls, in which the agency’s role has been scrutinized by Congress.
articles.abstract: The inquiry into the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration comes during a record year for recalls, in which the agency’s role has been scrutinized by Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: Concerned about safety lapses by the country’s top auto regulator, the Obama administration is undertaking a comprehensive review of the agency to determine if “we have the dial set correctly” on safety, a senior administration official with knowledge of the review said on Friday.
articles.byline: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Shareholders, Disarmed by a Delaware Court
articles.snippet: Under a recent ruling, a company can adopt bylaws requiring investors to pay its legal fees if they lose a lawsuit against it.
articles.abstract: Under a recent ruling, a company can adopt bylaws requiring investors to pay its legal fees if they lose a lawsuit against it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who will hold corporate executives and directors accountable for wrongdoing?

articles.headline: Dividing and Conquering the Trash
articles.snippet: Rubicon Global, a waste consultant, finds a lucrative niche in helping its business clients cut their hauling costs, and to recycle whatever they can.
articles.abstract: Rubicon Global, a waste consultant, finds a lucrative niche in helping its business clients cut their hauling costs, and to recycle whatever they can.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nate Morris pulled his rental Toyota Prius into a parking spot outside Bavarian Waste Services, a waste management company in rural Walton, Ky. Stepping out of the car, he inhaled the putrid odor wafting down from Bavarian’s landfill.

articles.headline: Bill Ackman and His Hedge Fund, Betting Big
articles.snippet: Whether fighting a corporate takeover war or buying a top-of-the-world apartment, the chief of Pershing Square Capital Management doesn’t hold back.
articles.abstract: Whether fighting a corporate takeover war or buying a top-of-the-world apartment, the chief of Pershing Square Capital Management doesn’t hold back.
articles.lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman, the silver-haired, silver-tongued hedge fund mogul, gestured out the window of a 42nd-floor conference room at Pershing Square Capital Management in Midtown Manhattan. The view was spectacular, but Mr. Ackman’s arm extended not downward, toward the vibrant fall foliage of Central Park, but skyward toward the top of a glittering glass building just around the corner on 57th Street.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: As Ebola Spread in Dallas, New York Honed Protocol
articles.snippet: Learning from missteps in the Dallas cases of Ebola, health workers and officials took a different approach in the case of a doctor who fell ill in New York.
articles.abstract: Learning from missteps in the Dallas cases of Ebola, health workers and officials took a different approach in the case of a doctor who fell ill in New York.
articles.lead_paragraph: This time was different.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise, Anemona Hartocollis, Sharon LaFraniere and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: Law Lets I.R.S. Seize Accounts on Suspicion, No Crime Required
articles.snippet: Using a law designed to help catch drug traffickers, racketeers and terrorists by tracking their cash, the government has gone after run-of-the-mill business owners and wage earners.
articles.abstract: Using a law designed to help catch drug traffickers, racketeers and terrorists by tracking their cash, the government has gone after run-of-the-mill business owners and wage earners.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARNOLDS PARK, Iowa — For almost 40 years, Carole Hinders has dished out Mexican specialties at her modest cash-only restaurant. For just as long, she deposited the earnings at a small bank branch a block away — until last year, when two tax agents knocked on her door and informed her that they had seized her checking account, almost $33,000.

articles.headline: The Horror Before the Beheadings
articles.snippet: The death of James Foley in August at the hands of Islamic State jihadists in Syria was a very public end to a hidden ordeal shared with nearly two dozen other Westerners.
articles.abstract: The death of James Foley in August at the hands of Islamic State jihadists in Syria was a very public end to a hidden ordeal shared with nearly two dozen other Westerners.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hostages were taken out of their cell one by one.

articles.headline: Daring Fare, From the Amazon’s Mouth to Yours
articles.snippet: A Brazilian chef who passed up the glamour of São Paulo is helping change his country’s cuisine with the help of flavors from the rain forest.
articles.abstract: A Brazilian chef who passed up the glamour of São Paulo is helping change his country’s cuisine with the help of flavors from the rain forest.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELÉM, Brazil — To start things off right at Thiago Castanho’s laboratory of Amazonian culinary revelations, take a sip of his signature cocktail, which blends cachaça, made from sugarcane, and jambu, an herb with analgesic properties whose flowers look like yellow and pink eyeballs. Sit back and let the jambu create a pleasant tingling sensation on the tongue.

articles.headline: For Midterms, Betting on Feet and Good Apps
articles.snippet: In few states has the ground game been as intense as in North Carolina, where both sides are marshaling outside money and advances in data analytics to reach out to voters.
articles.abstract: In few states has the ground game been as intense as in North Carolina, where both sides are marshaling outside money and advances in data analytics to reach out to voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — The foot soldiers in the battle for control of the Senate come well armed. With data-infused smartphones and tablets in hand, they have an unprecedented amount of information about the potential voters they are trying to persuade and more money than ever in a midterm election to do it.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Just 13 Banks Fail E.C.B. Stress Test, in Possible Economic Turning Point
articles.snippet: The European Central Bank said of the 130 banks it reviewed, only 13 lacked sufficient capital to withstand a severe crisis. But some analysts question the rigor of the exam.
articles.abstract: The European Central Bank said of the 130 banks it reviewed, only 13 lacked sufficient capital to withstand a severe crisis. But some analysts question the rigor of the exam.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The bulk of Europe’s biggest banks would be able to survive a financial crisis or severe economic downturn, the European Central Bank said on Sunday, concluding a yearlong audit of eurozone lenders that is potentially a turning point for the region’s battered economy.

articles.headline: Facebook Offers Life Raft, but Publishers Are Wary
articles.snippet: The company has suggested that publishers could simply send pages to Facebook that would live inside the social network’s mobile app.
articles.abstract: The company has suggested that publishers could simply send pages to Facebook that would live inside the social network’s mobile app.
articles.lead_paragraph: For publishers, Facebook is a bit like that big dog galloping toward you in the park. More often than not, it’s hard to tell whether he wants to play with you or eat you.

articles.headline: In Cold War, U.S. Spy Agencies Used 1,000 Nazis
articles.snippet: Law enforcement and intelligence leaders believed the ex-Nazis’ intelligence value against the Russians outweighed what one official called “moral lapses” in their service to the Third Reich, according to newly disclosed records.
articles.abstract: Law enforcement and intelligence leaders believed the ex-Nazis’ intelligence value against the Russians outweighed what one official called “moral lapses” in their service to the Third Reich, according to newly disclosed records.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the decades after World War II, the C.I.A. and other United States agencies employed at least a thousand Nazis as Cold War spies and informants and, as recently as the 1990s, concealed the government’s ties to some still living in America, newly disclosed records and interviews show.

articles.headline: Using Cash and Pressure, China Builds Its Chip Industry
articles.snippet: The Chinese government is investing billions in domestic chip makers as well as using legal action against multinationals and, experts say, espionage.
articles.abstract: The Chinese government is investing billions in domestic chip makers as well as using legal action against multinationals and, experts say, espionage.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China churns out many of the world’s electronic devices: smartphones, computers, complicated networking equipment.

articles.headline: How Facebook Is Changing the Way Its Users Consume Journalism
articles.snippet: Facebook uses mathematical formulas to predict what its users might want to read on the site, from which, a study says, about 30 percent of adults in America get their news.
articles.abstract: Facebook uses mathematical formulas to predict what its users might want to read on the site, from which, a study says, about 30 percent of adults in America get their news.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Many of the people who read this article will do so because Greg Marra, 26, a Facebook engineer, calculated that it was the kind of thing they might enjoy.

articles.headline: Missiles of ISIS May Pose Peril for Aircrews in Iraq
articles.snippet: There is strong evidence that Islamic State fighters in Iraq are using advanced surface-to-air missile systems that pose a serious threat to aircraft.
articles.abstract: There is strong evidence that Islamic State fighters in Iraq are using advanced surface-to-air missile systems that pose a serious threat to aircraft.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — From the battlefield near Baiji, an Islamic State jihadist fired a heat-seeking missile and blew an Iraqi Army Mi-35M attack helicopter out of the sky this month, killing its two crew members.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: The Bushes, Led by W., Rally to Make Jeb ‘45’
articles.snippet: As Jeb Bush nears a decision to become the third member of his storied family to seek the presidency, the extended Bush clan and its attendant network are largely rallying behind the prospect and pulling the old machine out of the closet.
articles.abstract: As Jeb Bush nears a decision to become the third member of his storied family to seek the presidency, the extended Bush clan and its attendant network are largely rallying behind the prospect and pulling the old machine out of the closet.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Jeb Bush decides whether to run for president, there will be no family meeting à la Mitt Romney, no gathering at Walker’s Point in Kennebunkport to go over the pros and cons. “I don’t think it’ll be like a big internal straw poll,” said his son, Jeb Bush Jr.

articles.headline: Seeking Unity, U.S. Revises Ebola Monitoring Rules
articles.snippet: The federal government announced guidelines that stopped short of tough measures in New York and New Jersey, while the Pentagon appeared to be setting its own course.
articles.abstract: The federal government announced guidelines that stopped short of tough measures in New York and New Jersey, while the Pentagon appeared to be setting its own course.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government on Monday tried to take charge of an increasingly acrimonious national debate over how to treat people in contact with Ebola patients by announcing guidelines that stopped short of tough measures in New York and New Jersey and were carefully devised, officials said, not to harm the effort to recruit badly needed medical workers to West Africa.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise, Michael D. Shear and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Living Wages, Rarity for U.S. Fast-Food Workers, Served Up in Denmark
articles.snippet: Some economists point to Denmark, where fast-food workers make more than twice what they would in the United States, in discussions about American wages.
articles.abstract: Some economists point to Denmark, where fast-food workers make more than twice what they would in the United States, in discussions about American wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — On a recent afternoon, Hampus Elofsson ended his 40-hour workweek at a Burger King and prepared for a movie and beer with friends. He had paid his rent and all his bills, stashed away some savings, yet still had money for nights out.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Steven Greenhouse
